column1: LESSON 10: Dashboard Basics - Making Data Beautiful
- A visual summary of your data on ONE screen
- Like the dashboard in a car but for your business
- Makes you look incredibly professional in meetings
If someone can't understand it in 5 seconds, redesign it
PART B: Setting Up Your Data Source
Good dashboards start with clean data
- Name it "SalesData" in Table Design tab
PART C: Creating Dynamic Ranges with OFFSET
Ranges that grow with your data!
PROBLEM: Normal ranges like A1:A100 are fixed
SOLUTION: OFFSET creates ranges that expand automatically
Go to: Formulas > Name Manager > New
The big numbers everyone looks at first
PRO TIP: Put these in a nicely formatted box at the top
PART E: Form Controls - Making It Interactive!
This is where the magic happens
4. Input range: Where your list items are
5. Cell link: Where the selection number goes
NOW MAKE CHARTS RESPOND TO IT! (See Part G)
3. Cell link: Points to a cell (TRUE/FALSE output)
Chart will show line when TRUE
- Cell link: Where to output the number
Scroll bar linked to cell N2
PART F: Sparklines - Mini Charts in Cells!
Tiny charts that fit in a single cell
PRO TIP: Use sparklines in KPI boxes to show trends!
PART G: Dynamic Charts That Respond to Controls
Cell K2 contains dropdown selection number (1-5)
- Chart automatically updates when dropdown changes!
PART H: Dashboard Layout Best Practices
1. KPIs at the TOP (what people look at first)
2. Main chart in the CENTER (the star of the show)
3. Filters on the SIDE or TOP (easy access)
- Align everything neatly (use Snap to Grid)
